The Supreme Court decides many of our nation’s most consequential cases, from elections to executions, with anonymous opinions shorter than the average tweet. This is known as the Court's "shadow docket."

I’m honored that my bill will be included as part of the Equality Act, our landmark legislation to affirm LGBTQ+ justice & equality by finally banning discrimination based on sexual orientation & gender identity.

Today, attorneys can legally discriminate against LGBTQ+ people when selecting juries.
I’m introducing the Juror Non-Discrimination Act to end this injustice & ensure no one is excluded from our legal system simply because of who they are or who they love. https://americanindependent.com/equality-act-legislation-bill-jury-lgbtq-jurors-courts-discrimination/

@RepMondaire hitting me where it hurts...

LGBTQ+ discrimination pervades every area of our society and the #EqualityAct is a powerful step toward affirming LGBTQ+ rights. 

As the first openly gay, Black member of Congress, this fight is personal to me and I’ll do everything in my power to get it across the finish line.

Gamifying day-trading, payment for order flow, and encouraging options trading prevent Robinhood from being a fiduciary to its customers, as required by Massachusetts law. Robinhood needs to make changes to protect its’ customers best interests.

Due to the complexity of options trading, new or casual investors are destined to lose out to experienced options traders.
 
68% of MA customers approved for options trading on @RobinhoodApp had limited to no investment experience.

Options are a complicated investment tool. Yes, they are a fast way to make money. They are also a fast way to lose money. Industry regulators require brokerages to vet customers who want to trade options. Robinhood, by contrast, pushes options onto its users.

Payment for order flow is Robinhood’s primary source of revenue and the reason it can offer commission-free trading to customers.
 
Doesn’t payment for order flow incentivize Robinhood to encourage customers to trade as often as possible regardless of their trade quality?
Robinhood must explain how it can claim to comply with Massachusetts’ best-interest rule when it clearly incentivizes everyday people to become day traders.

The vast majority of retail day traders, who try to pick individual stocks in competition with professional traders, lose money – and only about 1% consistently get better returns than low-cost index funds.

Right now, half of US households have no stocks at all. Democratizing access to assets is an important objective – we *want* Main Street to own more of Wall Street. However, the best way to do that is through low-cost index funds, mutual funds, or ETFs.

(3/4) Years ago, I authored the Stand by Your Ad rules to ensure transparency about “who approved this message” in campaign ads.

This bill strengthens and expands the existing disclosure requirements to account for online platforms.

(2/4) Lax rules allow so-called “independent” Super PACs to exercise huge influence in our elections and to indirectly coordinate with campaigns. 

The Stop Super PAC-Candidate Coordination Act would close these loopholes.

(1/4) Our campaign finance system urgently needs an overhaul.

That’s why I’m introducing the Stop Super PAC-Candidate Coordination Act and the Stand by Every Ad Act to reduce corporate and big money influence in elections.

Americans have mostly embraced these societal changes, appreciating the personal freedom & opportunities they have brought. But the downside has been reduced family stability, affecting children into adulthood & eroding no less than the social foundations of modern society.
The share of births to unmarried women began climbing in the mid-twentieth century and has increased dramatically. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EuiKNaEWgAMdEPN.jpg

Statistical tendencies cannot tell us what is best for individual children in specific circumstances. But they reinforce that children are likelier to be happy and successful when their parents intend to conceive a child together and subsequently maintain a healthy marriage.

It is no denigration to parents or children in other types of family arrangements to recognize that the married-parent family is unsurpassed as an institution for child development. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EuiKHgXWQAQXFDy.jpg

Of all the social relationships that shape people throughout their lives, none is so formative and consequential as the one children have with their parents. 
This report examined the rise in unwed childbearing as an indicator of declining social capital. 👇🏼

Judging on deaths alone, the data would imply that the New York City metro area was ineffective in its policy response as compared to the rest of the country. However, this may be too harsh a judgment. Find out how: https://www.jec.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/republicans/analysis?ID=8ACFB304-2B09-4BC4-A3B7-9946216BC150

While COVID cases and subsequent deaths were initially concentrated, known cases were widespread across states by June. Still, when respondents were specifically asked whether “getting married is more important to me than having a successful career,” only 19% agreed. 
https://jec.senate.gov/public/index.cfm/republicans/analysis?ID=733E5D3C-2FCD-4C23-B542-1C0213A8BDED

Marriage used to be a part of the path to achieving a stable life, today marriage is viewed as something that should happen only after people have established their careers and are financially secure. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EuhDOJdXUAcvVHJ.png
Could it be that marriage has come to be seen as a “capstone” of adulthood, rather than a “cornerstone” as it used to be? http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EuhDJppXcAQo7Oe.png
This is not too surprising, considering nearly 40% of children in the United States are born outside of marriage.
And while Americans overall seem to think that childbearing should take place within marriage, marriage does not seem to be as important a prerequisite to becoming a parent as are other factors.
However, recent studies show that marriage and parenting fall low on the list of what respondents considered essential to a fulfilling life.
Although family life in America has become less stable over the last several decades, the majority of the American population still agrees that marriage provides value to individuals and society.

This is about recovery, and it’s about rebuilding.

It’s about empowering ALL Americans – no matter who you are, where you live, or what kind of work you do.

We will show the American people – all people – that their government is on their side.

It's time to get to work.

We will get help to all people to stay in their homes and pay their bills.

We will keep the doors open at minority-owned businesses that entrepreneurs have worked their whole lives to build.

We will keep our buses and our trains running, and keep those workers on the job.

Black and brown workers don’t have to settle for a system that treats their lives as expendable.

Mothers don’t have to settle for doing three jobs.

Small business owners don’t have to settle for scraps.

Americans don't have to settle for a Wall Street-first recovery.

Today, under new leadership on this committee, we have a clear message: Those days are over.

We cannot and will not settle for less.

We are the world’s richest country with the world’s largest economy. We have the resources to rise to meet this challenge, for everyone.

It’s always the same story – when the biggest banks and corporations need help, their allies in Washington spring into action.

But when the rest of the country needs investment and support, they pretend we can’t afford it.

As for the toll this pandemic has taken on women, ask any mother how she’s doing right now. 

Millions of women have been doing three jobs for the last year:

full-time caregivers, teachers, and their pre-pandemic job.

Only one of those jobs actually comes with a paycheck.

This pandemic hasn’t just exposed racial disparities and income inequality and gender disparities – it’s made them worse.

The system has been making it harder for their work to pay off, and putting their lives at risk for generations – long before this virus appeared.

So many workers are one emergency away from draining what little savings they have or getting evicted.

If the bus stops running after 10 and they can’t make it to their night shift, they lose their job.

If their restaurant cuts their hours, they can't pay the bills.

For Black and brown workers, work has NEVER truly paid off like it should.

They were the first to be preyed on by shady mortgage lenders, the first to lose their jobs, and the first to get foreclosed on.

Long before the great recession, our trade and tax policy abandoned the industrial heartland and working class all over the country. 

People felt like their hard work no longer paid off. 

Now they feel like they’re watching history repeat itself.

Ohioans and working families all over the country know what that’s like.

They have too much experience watching the largest multinational corporations thrive, while our communities get left behind.

It should not be a surprise that our first hearing is about the coronavirus.

On this and on all of the issues to come before this committee, we are going to get to work for all the Americans who have not had much of a voice in Washington, or in our economy.

RT @AymanM Coming up at 3PM on @AymanMSNBC: @jacobsoboroff joins me with an exclusive interview with @SenatorMenendez on the 2021 U.S. Citizenship Act and President Biden’s immigration reform plan http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EuiFwG_WQAM0nbH.jpg

And to those who dare call this bill amnesty and preach xenophobia & hate: the status quo deprives us of the economic benefits of inclusive, lasting reform. Enough with this notion that immigration reform is somehow a loss to Republicans and not a win for America.

This bill will bring the 11 million out of the shadows, give them the opportunity to pass criminal background and national security checks, secure Lawful Prospective Immigrant Status, eventually apply for Green Cards & after 8 years begin the naturalization process.

We know the path forward will demand negotiations with the other side, but we will never win an argument we don’t have the courage to make. We must make our case for bold, inclusive and lasting immigration reform.

The 11 million undocumented are not "bad hombres.” They are Dreamers & TPS holders, farmworkers & meatpackers, relatives, friends and essential workers who kept our economy afloat in this pandemic. Immigration reform will make America stronger.

I’ve worked on immigration reform for nearly 30 years. The reason we haven’t gotten it done yet is not because Americans don’t support it. They do. The problem is we’ve capitulated too quickly to fringe voices that yell "amnesty" at anything accepting the humanity of immigrants.

Today, @RepLindaSanchez  & I unveiled the U.S. Citizenship Act, legislation that brings to life @POTUS’s plan to restore humanity and American values to our immigration system after four years of Trump’s hateful horror show.
